body: @guozhangwang, there is no way to revert an incorrect delete. If someone mistyped one config, there could be other issues in the command. It's much safer to fail the whole operation and let the user retry the whole thing. I can't think of a scenario where it's actually helpful to do a partial delete. Can you?
LGTM and merged to trunk.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.10/437/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).

The observation we had before is that although with a few number of clients it may help, with a large scale number of clients, it is likely that the broker's logs be swamped with error messages like such which will actually make debugging harder rather than easier.

One alternative approach would be adding the error logging on the client side if the connection get dropped, by doing this we will not put the heavy burden of logging on the server side but distribute them on the client side.
Merged to trunk.
@ewencp Looks like all the comments are addressed. I am still +1. Let me know if its good to merge.

Yeah, focusing on 1 & 2 makes sense. @ijuma Feels a bit weird to require a KIP to enforce an existing configuration correctly 😉 . That said, I'm not too sure about the impact, so might be safer to do a KIP anyway. Seems this only affects new clusters, so I imagine the main impact would be broken tests. Perhaps some broken deployment recipes also?

Thanks @rajinisivaram I reduced test duplication by introducing an intermediate abstract class in the test hierarchy. I could not avoid having `SslEndToEndAuthorizationTest` as a subclass of `SaslSetup` though due to the connection to zookeeper, but I think this is still cleaner

I don't see an advantage in combining both approaches. Can you elaborate? From my point of view, the current implementation with reset policy `none` covers what we need.

@guozhangwang What is your opinion? You suggested the change in the first place.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.11/442/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.11).
LGTM

Combining these two approaches sounds good to me, and just clarify a bit:

1. We do not require users to set the consumer reset policy to `none`, but we will always override it to `none` internally in `StreamsConfig`, just like what we did for `auto.commit.enabled`. But we will "remember" what user has set in the consumer config before overriding it in the streams layer.

2. Since it is set to `none`, we will expect exceptions thrown from `poll` if there is an out-of-range error, and we catch that exception by checking if there is an overridden reset policy for this stream (i.e. these topics), if yes seek to the specified position; otherwise use the global config that we remembered to seek.

3. Upon starting up, we still use `committed` to check if there is committed offsets or not.

cc @ijuma @guozhangwang

Why do we need to use `committted()`? On startup, consumer should pick up committed offsets automatically -- if they are valid, it just resumes, if they are not valid an exception occurs due to reset policy "none" and we seek according to specified reset strategy. Or do I miss anything?

This is a preview on the indented changes. Not everything is nice right now, but I want to give a first impression on my ideas about refactoring. If we agree on the way we want to do it, I can prepare a KIP for this change.
These are intentionally omitted to avoid them leaking into the source releases, which is not permitted by Apache rules. Check the mailing list for a couple of previous discussions around this issue.

Correct, there is no version matrix being tested currently.  The older versions will be enabled once KAFKA-4507 has been committed.  I have tested them locally and they work once the code enabling client compatibility is in place.  The main goal of committing this now is shrinking the size of the patch for client compatibility, and breaking it down into multiple JIRAs.  It also means that this feature will get done quicker because we are not blocked when committing this test.  Once KAFKA-4507 is in, we will test a matrix of older versions.

I think most of our other commands use two hyphens for the arguments, so the current patch seems appropriate. I guess the downside of this approach is that the `--version` option won't show up in any of the `--help` comments, so users might not know it exists without trying it out. That said, it's such a common flag, perhaps that's fine?
